Hi all, this is a design for Salt & Pepper. Easy to print and nice looking in two colours, You can print one with white Pla and one with black Pla.
Hope you have fun with it. Update 28.04.2015: I have add now the base as single, a Salt cap with 5 Holes in 2mm and a Pepper cap with 1 Hole in 2mm.

I have print it on Replikator 2 with 80% Scale .
Nothing Special to do, load it print it :-)
The Print you see in the Pictures is done in middle Quality on Replikator 2.
For bigger Prints 100%, you can use the single files, Bas, Cap Pepper and Cap Salt.

comments.text: Hi all, i have add now the files as single pieces with 2mm holes caps. :-)

comments.text: As @basten3d said, it would be nice if you reduce the holes.

comments.text: As @basten3d said, it would be nice if you reduce the holes.

comments.text: I made this salt & pepper shaker at 100% scale and the holes are way to big. I realize the instructions say to make it at 80% but then the capacity of the container would be way to small. The holes in the cap are 3 mm, which they only need to be 2 mm in diameter. Kind of makes it useless as a salt shaker.

title: Easy to print yet powerful parametric container

description.text:
Print a neat box to hold anything you want, be it pens, small items, coins, whatever!
You can download an STL file and print your container or even download an Openscad file and change the container the way you like it. The project is parametric and you can choose container size as well as number and size of the holes.

author: AuF

description.text: Need a ring with a personal touch? Easy to make your own version as the OpenSCAD file is optimized for Customizer. In Customizer your can change e.g. text, ring size and border. Ring size is in mm (inside circumference) - For conversion to other ring size definitions please refer to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_size The childrens cut in the bottom of ring is for more flexible wearing. This thing is a remake of the text rings in "Any Ring" optimized for customizer - Good luck.

Printed with 2 shells and 100% infill PLA using 0.1 mm resolution on the Makerbot Replicator 2 using rafts and typically support too.  
With these settings a ring will typically print in ~30 min.  
Print ring horizontally for maximum strength (remember support) - needed in particular for ring thickness below 2.5 mm.  
The New Year 2014 versions were printed upside down at 0.15 mm resolution in dual colour by changing filament during print using Z pause at 3 mm (including raft).

author: ajayre

title: Fitbit Zip box for dog collar

description.text:
A fixation to put a Fitbit Zip on a dog collar.
The fitbit Zip is in a box, it can't escape from its silicone pocket (removed) and the screen is more protected.

comments.text: Any ideas for making this waterproof? Our dogs always seem to find some water to wade through. Likely this box would end up on the bottom of their neck and be immersed.
comments.author: Cabriodad

comments.text: I used this box and a Fitbit Zip for almost 2 years without any issue, even my dog should have some beaver DNA looking to his attraction to water and stick  of wood. I put some grease on the screw of the Fitbit cover when I have to change the coin battery. It seemed to be enough to avoid water to go in during swimming session.I have also added a disk of blotting paper behind the battery to absorb moisture if any.
comments.author: Cabriodad

comments.text: This was one of the first designs I collected on thingiverse :) Now my dogs are doing to have a fitbit for christmas (together with the rest of their pack). However, I see you also made fixture for the fitbit one. Would you recommend me to get them the zip og the one?
comments.author: b2vn

comments.text: Hi, I strongly recommend the Zip one. One is power autonomy (up to 6 months depending on battery quality, no compromise there). So no need to charge each 4-5 days which is more convenient. Two is the LCD screen easy to read outdoor. The 3D box can be easily adapted to the width and thickness of any dog collar using google sketchup. I can do it if needed (give me the dimensions). My dog is wearing a Zip for more han 1 year now (https://www.fitbit.com/user/299YL3). My kids are using the steps number to feed him daily (10 000 steps is 2 cups, any extra 5 000 steps is 1/2 cup extra).
comments.author: b2vn

comments.text: Thank you. Zip it is then :) I'll let you know how it works after Christmas :)
comments.author: Klodeko

title: E3D V5 Fan Duct for MendelMax standard X Carriage

The original fan duct is too large and short to mount on standard X carriage on MendelMax 1.5 printer.
This duct fit between the support of linear bearings of the X carriage For E3D V6 version, go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:591458

Print this thing in ABS for prevent the melting of the duct. Set infill at 40%
The mounting is similar to the original duct.

author: Morti

title: Quick Change Replicator Reels with BONUS

description.text:
Save time when changing colors or materials by using this simple technique.
Oh... There's a DOUBLE bonus attached to this file now:-)

• Place the reel you want to change to near the rear of your Replicator.
  • Unclip the guide tube from the extruder you want to change from.
  • Feed the new plastic through the guide tube and let 3"- 4" hang from the end
  • Set the menu to unload the extruder.
  • As soon as the plastic releases, place the new plastic into the opening.
  • Stop the extruder and immediately set it to load. It will begin to draw the plastic in as soon as you press the button.
  • When you've loaded the extruder, pull the old plastic out of the guide tube, set the tube back onto the extruder and switch the reels at the rear of the machine... Done lickity-split :)
    • This will prevent the Replicator from shutting the heaters down while going through the motions of removing the old reel and loading the new. Check out the entire process here:
    http://www.instructables.com/id/Quick-Change-Color-on-Your-MakerBot-Replicator/ Now, for the bonus:
    Thingiverse loves to see objects posted. Rather than post a null file, here's something you may find useful: Those stupid little spacers that separate the fans from the cooling fins are a pain to put back into place. This may have been done before, but here's a spacer that connects the 2 center bolts, so you only have to wrestle with the outer spacers, which are far easier to install. Open the holes up with a 3.5mm drill. Enjoy. DOUBLE BONUS: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29036 I've modified a fan deck I'm using for another project. Might as well make things real easy and get all the spacers on one platform. Makes maintenance a non-issue.

comments.text: What is that cable chain sticking out of the side of your extruder for?
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Good eyesight... Good question.  The factory runs the fan wires between the extruders.  While this is a neat solution, the 2 bolts that hold everything together also use that space.  Bolts being harder than wire, they win any battle when trying to thread them into place.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: Just a note on the state of my extruders.  I'm working on a method to constantly measure the height of the heads above the plate and the build.  This is where I am now, which is not a good place (the dial gauge I'm using hits the forward portion of the wood case when it's heating up.  I'd cut the wood away, but that's also where the lights are mounted.  the reason it's still there, is because I've incorporated a snap-on cable holder that I think is superior to the cable ties that came with it and GeraldO's nifty little idea 21570 that was on there when those pictures were taken.
comments.author: LeftAngle

A model and 3 perl scripts for pushing the limits of your printer.
Caution: know and understand what your doing before attempting to use any of these.

This is a simple printer torture test designed to achieve a simple goal: how fast, how hot and how quick. The model will take a long time to slice in slic3r, however you need not necessarily use my model, any model with some height should be sufficient. each of these scripts tests the printer in the same way, as the printer goes up in the Z axis, all scripts ignore the first layer and all perl scripts work directly with gcode files. Caution: DO NOT set one of these up and then walk away, you should be paying attention here as there is a very good possibility of pushing your printer past some acceptable limits. The three scripts are:
speedup.pl - increases print speed using M220 as Z increases (default starts at 30% and increases by 3% at every layer change. At the top of the 50mm model your printer will be going around 500% faster then its current settings
tempup.pl - increases temperature of prints starting at T-10 and going to T+10 (where T is default print temperature it finds in the gcode file)
Accelup.pl - increases acceleration (starting at 500 and ramping up by 10 at every layer change), it uses M201 and M204 to do this. How do you use them
First you'll need perl, i havent bothered making compiled versions. Speedup.pl:
perl speedup.pl input.gcode output.gcode [start] [increment]
start is the M220 modifier at layer 2, increment is how much it changes each layer. For eg:
perl speedup.pl input.gcode output.gcode 200 1
would mean "modify the input.gcode file, output to output.gcode with a starting speed scale of 200, incrementing 1 after every layer change"
After you finish this print, make sure you issue a M220 S100 to revert back to normal speeds. Tempup.pl:
perl tempup.pl input.gcode output.gcode MAXTEMP [start] [layers] [increment]
I've put MAXTEMP in a required argument so you think about what temp you really want your extruder running at. This script will never exceed MAXTEMP.
start is the starting temperature (print temp minus 10 by default)
layers is how many layers between changes
increment is how many degrees to increase the temp at each change
For eg: perl tempup.pl input.gcode output.gcode 210 180 10 2
means, modify input.gcode into output.gcode with a MAXTEMP of 210, a starting temp of 180, change temperature every 10 layers by 2 degrees. (this uses M104 to modify temperature) accelup.pl:
perl accelup.pl input.gcode output.gcode [start] [incrememnt]
Does the same as speedup.pl, however modifies acceleration using M201 and M204
start - the acceleration at start (500 by default)
increment - per-layer incremental change (10 by default)
Note with this one: know what your acceleration values are prior to using it as in some firmwares, M201 and M204 are permanent changes
